title: CoPilot Quota Checks Hit When 3rd Party Provider is Used.

labels.name: invalid
labels.description: Issue identified as not relevant or not valid

body:
Type: Bug 1. Using OpenRouter with Free Account 2. Request Changes in Edit (Antrhopic | Claude Sonnet 4) via OpenRouter. Get partial response then error message "Free tier quota exceeded" Context. My openrouter key has plenty of money and I can see the request hit. The implications of this are quite bad as it means I'd be double charged if I was a paid co-pilot user. Somewhere in the extension code it's checking VSCode quotas even when OpenRouter is being used. This is very bad pls fix. It also means it's burned and will continue to burn my money to test and debug this. title: VScode crash
body:

title: Staging file in git through VSCode doesn't trigger filter
body:
Type: Bug I have a custom git filter: ``` cat .git/info/attributes src/**/*.c filter=indent ``` ``` $ git config --show-origin --get-regexp '^filter\.indent' file:.git/config filter.indent.clean astyle --style=google --indent=tab=8 --min-conditional-indent=3 --align-pointer=name --max-code-length=80 --break-after-logical --mode=c --lineend=linux ``` The `indent` filter applies to C files. So say that I have a C file that's being tracked in git `src/foo.c`: ```c struct foo { int a; int b; }; ``` My git tree is clean: ```sh $ git status On branch foo nothing to commit, working tree clean ``` If I update that file with just a whitespace change: ```c struct foo { int a; int b; }; ``` `git status` reports it changed: ```sh $ git status On branch leonardos/temp_rtl_dev Changes not staged for commit: (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed) (use "git restore ..." to discard changes in working directory) modified: src/foo.c no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a") ``` But `git diff` triggers the filter, so its output is empty: ```sh $ git diff ``` Staging a file also does nothing: ```sh $ git add src/foo.c $ git status On branch foo nothing to commit, working tree clean ``` Which is exactly was it's supposed to happen. Now, if I reset everything and apply the whitespace change again, the VSCode Source Control panel shows the file as changed. I can click on the `+` button to stage it. ```sh $ git diff --staged diff --git a/src/foo.c b/src/foo.c index f2aa23fb77ac..ad3819bce4e0 100644 --- a/src/foo.c +++ b/src/foo.c @@ -1,4 +1,4 @@ struct foo { int a; - int b; + int b; }; ``` As I demonstrated above, the `indent` filter should have been executed and I should not be able to stage anything. VS Code version: Code 1.104.1 (0f0d87fa9e96c856c5212fc86db137ac0d783365, 2025-09-17T23:36:24.973Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 4.18.0-553.56.1.el8_10.x86_64

title: Track the last focused chat message so that moving between chat input and response list is smoother for kb users

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

body: Idea from @rperez030 : Provide a mechanism to move between the input field and the chat thread without losing focus. Right now, Ctrl+Up Arrow always moves focus to the latest message in the thread. We would need a mechanism to return to the chat that moves focus not to the latest message, but to the last active message, knowing that not all Windows screen readers are good at respecting focus events in a web view.

title: Tree views: add the ability to have multiple columns and align them like a table
body: Add the ability to have multiple columns of text in a tree view item. It would be much easier to read if I could align the text in a tabular way. For example, in my extension, I have a `TreeDataProvider` and in each `TreeItem` I have 3 kinds of text: kind, path, and line. I'm currently using the em-space character `\u2003` as a separator. Here's what that looks like. I also tried the tab character `\t` and that works if the columns are very close. Here's a look at the tab. Neither case is great because the second column (file) is not aligned consistently.

title: Breadcrumb navigation within multi-diff editor
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I use the multi-diff editor for code reviews. One thing I'd like to have is better navigation within the multi-diff editor itself.

Currently, when I'm reviewing a large PR with many files, I have to scroll through hundreds of lines to find a specific file. [Issue #202019](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/202019) allows jumping from the sidebar to files in the multi-diff editor, which is great, but I'd like to navigate between files directly within the editor without opening any other views.

One way it could work would be to have breadcrumbs at the top of the multi-diff editor showing all the files, and when I click on a file name, it scrolls to that file. This would be similar to how regular breadcrumbs work but for the multi-diff view.

This would make reviewing large changesets much more efficient while staying focused in one editor.

title: Use custom icon for chatSessions to continue showing when FileIcon is turned off
body:
Fixes #265150

Chat Sessions is using VS Code's standard ResourceLabel component which respects global file icon theme settings. When file icons setting is turned off, global CSS rule .predefined-file-icon { display: none !important; } hides all icons rendered through this system.
This change implements a custom icon for Chat Sessions similar to Timeline and Outline views that bypasses the file icon theme.

title: Implement fallback to .well-known/oauth-protected-resource for MCP OAuth discovery
body:
## Problem

Currently, the MCP (Model Context Protocol) client in VS Code only supports OAuth discovery via the `WWW-Authenticate` header's `resource_metadata` parameter. According to [RFC 9728](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728), MCP clients **MUST** also support well-known URI fallback discovery when the header is not present or doesn't contain the required metadata.

This means VS Code fails to authenticate with MCP servers that only implement the well-known URI discovery method, limiting compatibility with compliant OAuth providers.

## Solution

This PR implements the missing RFC 9728 compliant fallback discovery mechanism. The implementation:

1. **Maintains existing behavior**: All current `WWW-Authenticate` header flows continue to work unchanged
2. **Adds fallback discovery**: When `resource_metadata` is not found in headers, attempts well-known URI discovery
3. **Follows RFC specification**: Implements the two required well-known URI patterns in correct order:
   - Path insertion: `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/public/mcp` 
   - Root fallback: `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource`

## Implementation Details

### New `fetchProtectedResourceMetadata` function in `oauth.ts`
- **Generic implementation**: Moved from MCP-specific code to reusable OAuth utility
- Constructs well-known URIs according to RFC 9728 patterns
- Attempts discovery in the specified order (path insertion first, then root)
- Configurable with custom fetch functions and same-origin headers
- Validates response format using existing type guards
- Handles errors gracefully and continues through discovery order

### Enhanced `_populateAuthMetadata` method in `McpHTTPHandle`
- Updated to use the new generic `fetchProtectedResourceMetadata` function
- Creates fetch adapter to bridge MCP's custom fetch with standard fetch API
- Maintains all existing functionality including same-origin header forwarding and MCP protocol version headers
- Preserves error handling and logging consistency

### Code quality improvements
- Extracted duplicate validation logic into `_validateResourceMetadata` helper
- Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation
- Follows existing code patterns and error handling conventions

## Testing

### Comprehensive test coverage added
- **10 focused test cases** in `oauth.test.ts` covering:
  - Correct discovery order (path insertion first, then root)
  - Error handling for network failures and invalid metadata
  - Same-origin header inclusion logic
  - Custom fetch function support
  - Various URL patterns (root URLs, complex nested paths)
  - Early return optimization on first successful response

### URL construction validation
- Simple root URLs: `https://example.com` → `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource`
- Path URLs: `https://example.com/api/mcp` → `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/api/mcp`
- Complex nested paths with proper fallback ordering

## Compliance

This change ensures VS Code's MCP client is fully compliant with RFC 9728 Section "Protected Resource Metadata Discovery Requirements", specifically:

> MCP clients **MUST** support both discovery mechanisms and use the resource metadata URL from the parsed WWW-Authenticate headers when present; otherwise, they **MUST** fall back to constructing and requesting the well-known URIs in the order listed above.

The implementation is backward compatible and adds no breaking changes - existing MCP servers using `WWW-Authenticate` headers will continue to work exactly as before.

Fixes microsoft/vscode#268210

Fixes microsoft/vscode#268210

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

title: Fallback to `.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` on 401s without `WWW-Authenticate`

labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

body:
here we assume that we are given a `WWW-Authenticate`:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/ba1d4ea9dd01fc6eff24764c1630bd0bd5b51a50/src/vs/workbench/api/common/extHostMcp.ts#L321-L351

in order to fetch the PRM (protected resource metadata)

... if we don't get that `WWW-Authenticate` we just assume there's no PRM.

But instead, we should look at `.well-known/oauth-protected-resource`

Here's what the spec says:

> #### Protected Resource Metadata Discovery Requirements
> 
> MCP servers **MUST** implement one of the following discovery mechanisms to provide authorization server location information to MCP clients:
> 
> 1. **WWW-Authenticate Header**: Include the resource metadata URL in the `WWW-Authenticate` HTTP header under `resource_metadata` when returning `401 Unauthorized` responses, as described in [RFC9728 Section 5.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728#name-www-authenticate-response).
>
> 2. **Well-Known URI**: Serve metadata at a well-known URI as specified in [RFC9728](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9728). This can be either:
>   * At the path of the server's MCP endpoint: `https://example.com/public/mcp` could host metadata at `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource/public/mcp`
>   * At the root: `https://example.com/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource`
>
> MCP clients **MUST** support both discovery mechanisms and use the resource metadata URL from the parsed WWW-Authenticate headers when present; otherwise, they **MUST** fall back to constructing and requesting the well-known URIs in the order listed above.

It's odd to me that there are these 2 bullets, one for injecting, one at the root... the code logic for supporting both of these can be generalized to just follow the first bullet.

title: font/fontsize/background image/etc for user interface setting
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Some extensions exist to partially solve this problem, but I believe this functionality should be available in VS Code by default.  

In my case, I use NixOS, and it is not possible to modify VS Code’s installed files because they live in the read-only nix-store. This means I cannot change the UI background, UI font, or use extensions that inject custom animations.  

It would be great if VS Code provided either:  
- A default setting to customize the UI font/background, **or even better**  
- A supported way to load custom JS/CSS from the user’s home directory (on Unix-like systems) without requiring root privileges.  

This would make customization more accessible, especially for environments like NixOS, where modifying system files is not feasible.

title: Feature request: parallel copilot sessions
body:
This feature request has already been made here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/242318

But that issue was close without a satisfactory follow-up.

Currently in VS Code, the OpenAI Codex extension already allows parallel execution by simply creating a new chat.

The copilot extension immediately stops the current chat if a new one is created. This is clearly not optimal behavior as it is very unlikely for the user's intention to be to stop the current chat by creating a new one. If the intention was to stop the currently ongoing one, they would stop it explicitly instead of just creating a new chat.

Simply opening a new chat is also the simplest, most obvious and least friction way of starting a new parallel session.

For that reason I consider this to be worth consideration, especially given that a competitor has already implemented it.

title: Add `toolMetadata` support to Language Model Tool Results
body:
Enables tools to attach arbitrary metadata to results for enhanced chat extension integration.

## Changes
- Add `toolMetadata?: any` to `IToolResult` and `ExtendedLanguageModelToolResult`
- Dynamic property forwarding in type converters

**Related:** Chat extension will use this for tool logs analytics. microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat#1131

title: Sticky Scroll slows down response to arrow keys motion
body:
Type: Performance Issue After a while (15 min? 30 min?) working on a Python file ~200 lines long, the caret motions using arrow keys get slower and slower until it becomes too uncomfortable to work with, in particular while pressing and holding those keys. I use Python Environments extension (includes "Pylance", "Python Debugger" and "Python" language support) and vscodevim Vim emulator. However, the issue still remains when I disable all the extensions, close the "big" file and reopen it. Closing and reopening VS Code solves the problem temporarily until it comes back. **Disabling and re-enabling "Sticky Scroll"** (View>Appearance>~) also solves it, temporarily! title: Agent is now the default - update ChatMode.Ask hardcoded assumptions

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
In the next 10 days we will roll out Agent as default to all users world wide (including Free users).
Thus we should go through the code and change all our ChatMode.Ask hardcoded assumptions. And make sure that we default to ChatMode.Agent (even if user has no internet connection / ExP).

There might be other potential debt items we need to tackle in this new world of everyone having Agent by default?

fyi @bpasero

title: Test Issue for Tool Classification
body: This is a test issue to verify tool classification functionality.
